div1.p: Reed discusses a lawsuit concerning his reputation and his brother Christopher Reed's excessive exertions on his behalf. [Courtesy of the Library of Virginia]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, April 13, 1874
div1.opener:
Office of the Sanitary Superintendent
No. 66 Court Street 115 Lee Ave.
Brooklyn, April 13th, 1874.
My dear Sis,
div1.p:
I received a letter from Kit, this morning, & also
a short note from yourself - Surely Kit is “beside
himself” from the manner in which he writes. His wrath
is like the Eruption from some mighty volcanoe. And what
amuses me, he sends me letters in which he breathes wrath
& threatenings against all mankind, evidently showing
himself to be in the a state of the highest excitement &
anger, & at the same time urging me to be calm & get out of the
matter peoplepeaceably - He might, at least show me an example of
calmness, and not be writing to me as if he considered
me a nieve babe - Why, great Heavens! he regrets that
he cannot be in New York to look after my affairs!
Well, if he carried on in my presence, as he does
in his writing, I am of the opinion that a separa-
tion of a few hundred miles is decidedly to my
benefit - Mark what I say: I know that Kit means
to assist me all he can, thinks that his advice is
good, & would do anything he could to help me out of
my difficulties, but he certainly does not know
how to hold his temper. I am bad enough; Kit is
worse. If it had not been for my hot head &
his hot head, I never should have never been in
the trouble. We both of us plunged into the suit,
like 2 mad bulls, without considering for one
moment what would be the termination. I was smarting
under the slander which had been uttl uttered against
me by an ignorant Dutchman; slander which could
not have & did not do me any possible damage-
charges which no one ever believed & of which
I was immediately cleared upon an investigation.
No, into it I would go - what did I know about the
law? Kit said it was a good case -- another
hot-headed Virginian said the same, and like 3
blind jack-asses, as we were, we took aim & fired
our little thunder-bolt, which, at first, went “whiz-
zing” through the air A tStraight at the unfortunate
dutchman, & when we were congratulating ourselves
that he would soon “squeel” from the effect of a
smart blow, lo! behold, the thunderbolt changed
its course, & in spite of all the laws of gravity,
described a circle and took me plumb on the
head, making the sparks fly out, in the shape of
dollars. The whole thing is simply ridiculous, and
I wouldn't take $500 dollars for it. It has learned
me a lesson that I shall never forget & one which will
be of immense benefit to me. I am entirely
too impulsive - You can depend upon it, I will
next time, think before I leap - I know Kit is worried,
but what good will that effect? He seems to be afraid
that my money is going into the large pockets of “that
dog Mattern,” (as he dubs him) - Well he won't get enough
to buy his old lady a dress - He is entitled to what he
gets because he has purjured himself & he will
need something to keep his spirits up - If he will tell

as many lies as he has told for $50, I consider that he
does his work remarkably cheap - The time is coming
when he would gladly pay that amt. to have that his
lies blotted out. It is a gratification to know that
my action has been perfectly honorable since I com-
menced the suit - I have been deceived by some men to
a slight extent, but has not it has not damaged
me in the least. In fact, I never was happier, or
more calm & contented. As for my doing anything
“rash”, never you fear that. I have a tolerably evenly
balanced head on my shoulders - & it was never
was better balanced than it is to-day - It has been
recently shaken & clarified. Kit talks about men
“eating me up” - “sucking my life's blood” - “sapping” me “ -
“picking” me, and a lot of terrible accidents - He forgets
that I am a medical man & have seen some blood
in my day - The man who tries to “eat me up,” will
find a rather tough morsel - I must give Kit credit
for writing letters that would frighten the “wax”
out of a fellow! I thought Mattern was prepa-
ring to hurl the Egyptian plagues at me. Let me
enumerate a few of his words -- “They will pick you” - “suck
the blood out you”-“Pryor is a grabber” - “he is a farce” - “Segur is
an archangel of treachery” - “a liar” - “a scoundrel”-“desertion”-“you will
be skinned”-and then after telling me that I am the “Victim
of Malicious men,” he throws off the mild sentence:
“As for Dr Segur, if I were a special messenger, commis-
sioned by God Almighty to search the vocabulary of
Hell, I could not find language sufficiently strong
to portray his damnable rascality” - How is that for
laying it on “heavy” - I want Kit to read this and ask
himself whether such language is at all refrigerating.
I am sorry that he has written anything to Logan.
It cannot possibly do any good & it may do me
much harm - For goodness sake, let him send
me all his extra fire and brimstone & not
to other people. I am afraid Kit's visit has not
been very pleasant thus far - well, let everything
go smoothly now. I am out of my trouble & there
is no use of Kit “ripping” around (as I know he
does) like a little black bull stung in the St nStern
by a hornet! Upon my soul, as I write, I am
roaring with laughter - I only wish I could see
Kit for about half an hour; we would have some
jolly good fun - But I must close, Excuse all
mistakes, as I have written in a great hurry,

closer.salute:
Love to all,
Your affectionate Bro.
